comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Probably Monte Cassino after the 1944 fighting. See www.lancs-fusiliers.co.uk/BattlehonoursXXthoffoot.htm for an English regiment that fought there and provides a similar view: www.lancs-fusiliers.co.uk/Calendar/a2008/New%20Folder/cas... See also en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Monte_Cassino "The Battle of Monte Cassino (also known as the Battle for Rome and the Battle for Cassino) was a costly series of four assaults by the Allies against the Winter Line in Italy held by the Germans and Italians during the Italian Campaign of World War II. The intention was a breakthrough to Rome." The Wikipedia page gives the battle's dates as 17 January – 18 May 1944.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: There pictures of the battlefield, taken at or near the time and much more recently, at: www.cassinobattlefields.co.uk/page5.php www.cassinobattlefields.co.uk/page6.php

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: More about the battle at www.ourstory.info/4/e/4e4a3.html "Monte Cassino, or Monastery Hill, was the keystone of the enemy's defences. It was a rocky spur which rose steeply from the plain to a height of about 1700 feet. On the top was the Abbey. To the north of it there was a deep chasm, and to the north-west the mountain ridge along which the Americans had advanced, almost reaching the fortified hilltop Point 593 and Mount Castellone. Beyond Monte Cassino again was the majestic, snow-capped Monte Cairo. "

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: See www.flickr.com/photos/smu_cul_digitalcollections/sets/721... for another set of Monte Cassino photos in Flickr Commons
